div.p: To the esteemed Balthasar, as he departs to you, I could not refrain from sending a letter, especially since today I received from you a letter full of love and goodwill. This has been the most gratifying occurrence amidst my other troubles and inconveniences, that I find you, a good man distinguished in all good arts, becoming more friendly to me each day. I willingly confess, I am delighted to be honored by your judgment and I consider it a special favor, so that I may diligently strive in the future to ensure that whatever judgment and duty you have bestowed upon me, you will deem well-placed.
I am grateful that you inform me about German affairs; nothing of great disturbance seems to be feared there. I have learned about the Turkish fleet through the talk and letters of many.
Our affairs in France are in a fairly good state. The King is in Toulouse, where there is much for him to do.

May God mercifully be present to the youth of our prince and grant the Christian name, you and me, His peace. Farewell, most excellent man, to whom I wish the greatest health, to your consuls and republic, and to Gwalter and Gesner.
Chur, on the first of March, 1565.
To the most distinguished man, Lord Heinrich Bullinger, most worthy pastor of the Church of Zurich.
